item.title: Crystal Palace FC Backer Eagle Files Confidentially for US IPO
item.description: Eagle Football Holdings Ltd., one of the most active investors in football clubs globally, has filed confidentially for a US initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier

media:content.media:description: Crystal Palace's midfielder Jeffrey Schlupp heads the ball during a match between Liverpool and Crystal Palace in Liverpool, England, on May 25, 2025.

item.title: Fmr US Amb to Iraq on Cconflict Between Israel-Iran
item.description: James Jeffrey, Former US Ambassador to Iraq & Turkey speaks with Romaine Bostick about the current conflict between Israel and Iran. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sports Teams Now Run Like Tech Startups: Fmr. NFL Player
item.description: Andrew Kline, Park Lane Founder & Former St. Louis Rams Lineman speaks with Romaine Bostick about the rising valuations of sport teams. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ecuador Expected to Delay New Mining Fee, Industry Leader Says
item.description: Ecuador has indicated that it will delay the implementation of a new mining fee estimated to generate $229 million annually, according to Rodrigo Darquea, vice president of the country’s mining chamber.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner

media:content.media:description: The entrance to the Bira mine in Zaruma, Ecuador, on Thursday, April 28, 2022. Illegal mining has polluted waterways and sinkholes are swallowing the colonial houses of Zaruma, an Ecuadorian town that was literally built on gold and aspires to be a UNESCO world heritage site.

item.title: 23andMe Co-Founder Wins Auction for Genetic Data
item.description: The co-founder of bankrupt genetic analysis company 23andMe won an auction for the firm’s assets, agreeing, along with a California research institute, to pay $305 million for a cache of customer DNA data
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Anne Wojcicki, chief executive officer and co-founder of 23andMe Inc., speaks during the 2020 Makers Conference in Los Angeles, California, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 11, 2020. The event gathers industry leading females for roundtable discussions to help inspire the women of tomorrow.

item.title: JPMorgan Readies $6.5 Billion Skechers Debt Sale for Next Week
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. plans to kick off a $6.5 billion debt offering to support private equity firm 3G Capital’s purchase of footwear maker Skechers as soon as next week, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jeannine Amodeo

media:content.media:description: Sneakers in a Skechers store in Times Square in New York, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. Investment firm 3G Capital will acquire footwear maker Skechers USA Inc. for $8.2 billion, the company said in a statement on Monday.

item.title: Belgium’s Credit Rating Cut by Fitch as Budget Concerns Linger
item.description: Belgium’s sovereign credit was cut by Fitch Ratings, signaling an increase in uncertainty about the country’s ability to rein in years of substantial debt accumulation.
item.dc:creator: Michal Kubala, Lyubov Pronina

item.title: Columbia Graduate Still in Custody After Frantic Day of Appeals
item.description: A Columbia University graduate who participated in pro-Palestinian protests will remain in custody at an immigration facility after a federal judge said the government could detain him over alleged problems with his green card application.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil Photographer: Selcuk Acar/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Rational Moves in the Market: Nuveen's Persson
item.description: The conflict between Iran and Israel sent volatility through the global markets, Nuveen CIO for Global Fixed Income Anders Persson says the moves though have been "rational”. He speaks with Sonali Basak on "Real Yield." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall Street’s Momentum Machine Faces a Middle East Stress Test
item.description: It’s the kind of geopolitical flashpoint that might once have triggered a full-blown market meltdown: Israeli warplanes struck Iranian nuclear sites, Tehran vowed revenge — then followed through. Oil spiked.
item.dc:creator: Denitsa Tsekova, Emily Graffeo

media:content.media:description: TEHRAN, IRAN - JUNE 13: The view from a living room of a residential building that was destroyed in an attack by Israel on June 13, 2025 in Tehran, Iran. Early this morning, Iran was hit by a series of Israeli airstrikes targeting military and nuclear sites, as well as top military officials. (Photo by Majid Saeedi/Getty Images)

item.title: Dollar’s Tepid Rebound Reinforces Questions Around Haven Role
item.description: The dollar’s muted rally against major peers after Israel’s strikes on Iran reinforced the impression that the greenback’s role as a global haven currency is fading.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson, Ruth Carson, Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: Stacks of U.S. $100 bills are arranged for a photograph in New York, U.S., on Thursday, Feb. 7, 2013. The U.S. dollar advanced in trading today to the highest in almost three weeks against a basket of major currencies.

item.title: Dye & Durham’s Ex-CFO Urges Sale After Stock Drops, Debt Mounts
item.description: A former senior executive and shareholder of Canadian technology firm Dye & Durham Ltd. is asking the board to consider a full sale of the company, citing a plunge in shareholder value and growing competitive pressures.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

item.title: Travel Stocks Sink, Energy Soars as Israel Strikes Iran
item.description: Israel’s strikes on Iran rippled through the US stock market on Friday, sinking shares of travel companies and lifting energy and defense stocks as traders braced for the possibility of a wider Middle East conflict.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin, Peyton Forte, Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, May 19, 2025. A renewed wave of dip buying fueled a rebound in stocks from session lows, with traders trying to look past the US downgrade by Moody’s Ratings that has sent bond yields climbing and weakened the US dollar. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Stocks Sink, Oil Jumps as Mideast Tensions Build: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street buckled as reports of Iran’s retaliation for Israel’s attack on its nuclear facilities deepened concerns that the conflict is escalating, with oil jumping and stocks taking a hit.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: S&P 500 Suffers Weekly Loss as Middle East Conflict Intensifies
item.description: The US stock market snapped a two-week winning streak as investors piled into safe haven assets after Israel launched military strikes on Iran, followed by retaliation from Tehran, with traders fearing the clash may spiral into a wider global and economic conflict.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

media:content.media:description: First-responders outside a building that was hit by an Israeli strike in Tehran, on June 13.

item.title: Trump Plans Biofuel Quota Boost, Seeks to Crimp Imports
item.description: The Trump administration is proposing oil refiners blend more biofuels into gasoline and diesel next year, while seeking to discourage the use of imported supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kim Chipman

media:content.media:description: A Phillips 66 renewable fuels refinery in Rodeo, California.

item.title: Felicis Ventures Raises Its Largest Fund
item.description: Felicis Ventures Managing Partner Sundeep Peechu discusses how the firm plans to target AI investments with its latest $900 million fundraise. Peechu joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Jumps as Mideast Tensions Build | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hedge Funds Ramped Up Bullish Oil Bets Ahead of Israel’s Attack
item.description: Hedge funds took the most bullish stance on US crude since January in the week before Israel launched strikes against Iran’s nuclear program, putting them in a position to profit from this week’s jump in oil prices.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: Pumpjacks extract oil near Monahans, Texas.

item.title: Europe Set to Move a Step Closer to Halting Russian Gas Imports
item.description: The European Union is expected to take a major step next week toward curbing Russian gas imports starting next year with aims to sever ties with its former top supplier by the end of 2027.
item.dc:creator: Ewa Krukowska

item.title: Addressing AI’s Impact on the Gender Gap
item.description: Artificial intelligence data sets need to better represent women, says Shubhi Rao, Founder and CEO of Uplevyl, a platform designed to accelerate women in the workplace. Rao speaks with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Addresses The People of Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addressed the people of Iran directly after an early morning military strike. He warned "more is on the way." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Drone Maker Airo Jumps 140% in Latest Post-IPO Debut Pop
item.description: Airo Group Holdings Inc. shares climbed 140% in their public trading debut on Friday after the company raised $60 million in an initial public offering, becoming the third company this month to more than double during its opening session.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

item.title: Visa, Mastercard Tumble as Merchants Eye Stablecoins
item.description: Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. fell, with Visa slipping as much as 7.1% and Mastercard dropping as much as 6.2%. Both declines were the biggest for the shares of companies since April. Meanwhile, Amazon.com Inc. and Walmart Inc. are among large multinational companies which have recently discussed issuing their own stablecoins in the US, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified people. Bloomberg's Michael Regan has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Visa, Mastercard Tumble as Merchants Eye Stablecoins | Bloomberg Markets 6/13/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Middle East Institute Vice President For Policy Kenneth Pollack, Bloomberg's Mishal Husain, and David Welch. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Adobe Fails to Convince AI Skeptics with Sales Outlook
item.description: Adobe’s sales outlook wasn’t enough to convince investors that the software maker can outduel AI-focused upstarts. Bloomberg’s Brody Ford tells Caroline Hyde why on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: What the Israel-Iran Conflict Means for Oil Output and Prices
item.description: Rebecca Babin, CIBC Private Wealth Group senior energy trader, discusses what the Israel-Iran conflict could means for oil markets on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Apple Sets Plans for Delayed Siri Launch in 2026
item.description: Apple is targeting spring 2026 for the release of its delayed Siri upgrade, as the iPhone maker works to turn around its AI efforts. Bloomberg’s Mark Gurman joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Meta Finalizes Investment and Acquihire of Scale AI
item.description: Meta has finalized its $14.3 billion investment into Scale AI and plans to hire the company’s CEO to join the social media giant's new "superintelligence" team. Bloomberg’s Kurt Wagner discusses the deal with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Geopolitical Tensions Weigh on Tech Investors
item.description: Mike Reynolds, vice president of investment strategy at Glenmede, says investors should not react too quickly to tensions in the Middle East, but cautions that ongoing fighting could impact energy costs. Reynolds joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)
